title: Definite integral and composite accumulation f

content.question:
Let g be the piecewise-linear function defined on [-2π, 4π] whose graph is given above, and let <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mi>cos</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mfrac> <mi>x</mi> <mn>2</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@45AA@</annotation> </semantics> </math>.

(a) Find <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mi>π</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>4</mn> <mi>π</mi> </mrow> </msubsup> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4394@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

frqParts.text:
Let g be the piecewise-linear function defined on [-2π, 4π] whose graph is given above, and let <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mi>cos</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mfrac> <mi>x</mi> <mn>2</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@45AA@</annotation> </semantics> </math>.

(a) Find <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mi>π</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>4</mn> <mi>π</mi> </mrow> </msubsup> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4394@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.
(b) Find all x-values in the open interval (−2π, 4π) for which f has a critical point.

topic.text: 5.2: Extreme Value Theorem, Global Versus Local Extrema, and Critical Points

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
